title: Trade surplus down on lower iron ore price
text:
While Treasury makes conservative estimates of forward iron ore prices, the federal government will be monitoring closely just how much iron ore prices ease and how this affects company profits that underpin the federal budget.

The federal budget's return to virtual "balance" last month put the Morrison government on track to achieve the first surplus in 12 years.

China's insatiable appetite for mining commodities has underpinned the trade surplus and exports to that country are posting fresh highs.

Figures released this week showed that Australia's share in the value of exports to China reached a record 38 per cent or $117 billion – more than any other country. In August, Australia exported $13 billion to China, well over twice as much as our nearest trading partner Japan, with $5 billion. Trade with the US was $1.2 billion in August.

"It is clear that Australia has a vested interest in wanting the Chinese economy to do well. But we are also posting near record exports with the US," CommSec economist Craig James said.

"The US-China trade war isn’t hurting Australia but clearly we would be hoping for some resolution of the trade stoush when talks are held late next week."

Drought fears

Some economists, such as NAB's Tapas Strickland, have warned that drought could start to effect our exports of resources.

"Going forward we will be watching coal exports, given there have been a number of warnings by mining companies that the severe east coast drought was draining water supplies in the dams that supply a number of gold mines, an issue that could also affect the quality of coal production as well," Mr Strickland said.

"At this stage though, this is still largely speculative and effects would only appear if the drought does not break."

While rural exports are down 9.6 per cent in the last year they rose by 1.4 per cent in the month of August.
description: Australia's monthly trade surplus has dipped back to $5.9 billion in August after hitting a record $8 billion in June, mainly due to a reduction in iron ore, coal and rural exports.
